docs.title: Admin ui
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Admin UI Service Documentation

## Overview

The **admin_ui** service is a critical component of the Vivified platform, designed to provide a secure and user-friendly administrative interface for managing enterprise data and configurations. As a HIPAA-compliant service, it ensures the protection and confidentiality of health information.

!!! note
    This service is part of the Vivified platform's suite of HIPAA-compliant enterprise solutions, ensuring that all data handling meets stringent regulatory standards.

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[User] -->|Access| B[admin_ui Service];
    B -->|Retrieve| C[Data Layer];
    B -->|Send| D[Audit Logs];
    C -->|Process| E[HIPAA-Compliant Storage];
```

## Key Features
- Secure admin interface for managing platform settings.
- Audit logging for all administrative actions.
- Integration with the Vivified data layer to ensure data integrity and compliance.

## Security Considerations

!!! warning
    Ensure all users accessing the admin_ui service have appropriate permissions and undergo regular security training to maintain compliance.

- **Access Control**: Implement role-based access control (RBAC) to restrict access.
- **Encryption**: All data in transit and at rest is encrypted using industry-standard protocols.
- **Audit Logging**: Every action within the admin_ui is logged for audit purposes, with logs stored securely.
",
  "api": "# Admin UI API Reference

The admin_ui service provides a RESTful API for programmatic access to its features.

## Authentication
All API endpoints require an API key and OAuth2 token for access.

## Endpoints

### GET /api/admin/settings
Retrieve current platform settings.

```json
{
  "endpoint": "/api/admin/settings",
  "method": "GET",
  "description": "Retrieve current platform settings."
}
```

### POST /api/admin/settings
Update platform settings.

```json
{
  "endpoint": "/api/admin/settings",
  "method": "POST",
  "description": "Update platform settings."
}
```

!!! tip
    Use the POST method with caution, ensuring that all changes are compliant with organizational policies.
",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

## Configuration Options

The admin_ui service can be configured using the following options:

| Option        | Type    | Default | Description                                      |
|---------------|---------|---------|--------------------------------------------------|
| `port`        | Integer | 8080    | The port on which the service listens.           |
| `log_level`   | String  | info    | The level of logging detail (info, debug, warn). |
| `data_source` | String  |         | Connection string for the data source.           |

### Example Configuration

```yaml
port: 8080
log_level: info
data_source: "postgres://user:password@localhost:5432/admin_db"
```
",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

## Accessing the Admin UI

=== "Python"
    ```python
    import requests

    url = "https://vivified-platform.com/api/admin/settings"
    headers = {
        "Authorization": "Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN",
        "Content-Type": "application/json"
    }
    
    response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
    print(response.json())
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    curl -X GET "https://vivified-platform.com/api/admin/settings" \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN" \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json"
    ```

## Updating Settings

=== "Python"
    ```python
    import requests
    import json

    url = "https://vivified-platform.com/api/admin/settings"
    headers = {
        "Authorization": "Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN",
        "Content-Type": "application/json"
    }
    
    data = json.dumps({"setting_key": "new_value"})
    response = requests.post(url, headers=headers, data=data)
    print(response.status_code)
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    curl -X POST "https://vivified-platform.com/api/admin/settings" \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN" \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    -d '{"setting_key": "new_value"}'
    ```

## Troubleshooting

!!! note
    Always ensure your API key and access tokens are valid.

- **403 Forbidden**: Check if your API key has the necessary permissions.
- **500 Internal Server Error**: Verify that the service is running and accessible.
- **400 Bad Request**: Ensure JSON payloads are correctly formatted and contain all required fields.
"
}

docs.title: Api
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Vivified Platform API Service Documentation

The **Vivified API Service** is a crucial component of the Vivified platform, designed to handle authentication, user management, configuration settings, and notifications. As a HIPAA-compliant service, it ensures the protection of sensitive health information through robust security measures.

## Architecture Overview

The service is built using FastAPI, supporting asynchronous operations and providing a high-performance environment for handling RESTful API requests.

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Client] -->|HTTP Request| B[API Gateway];
    B --> C[Auth Module];
    B --> D[Admin Module];
    B --> E[Notifications Module];
    C --> F[Identity Service];
    D --> G[Database];
    E --> H[Notifications Service];
```

!!! note
    The API service is part of a larger microservices architecture, with each service component interacting via well-defined interfaces.

",
  "api": "# API Reference

## Authentication

### Login

- **Endpoint:** `/auth/login`
- **Method:** POST

#### Request

```python
class LoginRequest(BaseModel):
    username: str
    password: str
```

=== "Python"
```python
import requests

url = "http://example.com/auth/login"
payload = {
    "username": "your_username",
    "password": "your_password"
}
response = requests.post(url, json=payload)
print(response.json())
```

=== "curl"
```
curl -X POST "http://example.com/auth/login" \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{"username": "your_username", "password": "your_password"}'
```

#### Response
- **Success:** Returns authentication token and user details.
- **Failure:** HTTP 401 with "Invalid credentials".

## User Management

### Get Current User

- **Endpoint:** `/auth/me`
- **Method:** GET

#### Response
Returns user id and traits.

=== "Python"
```python
import requests

url = "http://example.com/auth/me"
headers = {
    "Authorization": "Bearer your_token"
}
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())
```

=== "curl"
```
curl -X GET "http://example.com/auth/me" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer your_token"
```

## Notifications

### List Notifications

- **Endpoint:** `/admin/notifications`
- **Method:** GET

#### Response
Returns a list of notifications.

=== "Python"
```python
import requests

url = "http://example.com/admin/notifications"
headers = {
    "Authorization": "Bearer your_token"
}
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())
```

=== "curl"
```
curl -X GET "http://example.com/admin/notifications" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer your_token"
```

",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

Below is a table of key configuration options for the API service:

| Option          | Description                                       | Default Value |
|-----------------|---------------------------------------------------|---------------|
| `key`           | Configuration key, max length of 255 characters   | None          |
| `value`         | Configuration value, can be any type              | None          |
| `is_sensitive`  | Boolean to mark if the value is sensitive         | False         |
| `reason`        | Optional reason for configuration change          | None          |

!!! tip
    Sensitive configurations should be encrypted to adhere to HIPAA compliance standards.

## Security Considerations

- **Authentication:** Implement strong password policies and multi-factor authentication.
- **Data Encryption:** All sensitive data, including PHI, must be encrypted both at rest and in transit using AES-256.
- **Access Control:** Utilize role-based access control (RBAC) to restrict access to sensitive endpoints and data.

",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

## Python Example

```python
import requests

login_url = "http://example.com/auth/login"
me_url = "http://example.com/auth/me"

# Login and get token
login_payload = {
    "username": "your_username",
    "password": "your_password"
}
login_response = requests.post(login_url, json=login_payload)
login_data = login_response.json()

token = login_data.get("token")

# Get current user information
headers = {
    "Authorization": f"Bearer {token}"
}
me_response = requests.get(me_url, headers=headers)
print(me_response.json())
```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

- **Issue:** HTTP 401 Unauthorized
  - **Solution:** Ensure that the username and password are correct and the account is active.

- **Issue:** Notifications service unavailable
  - **Solution:** Verify that the Notifications Service is running and accessible. Check network configurations and service logs for errors.

!!! warning
    Ensure all API requests utilize secure HTTPS connections to prevent data interception.

"
}

docs.title: Audit
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Audit Service Overview

The Audit Service in the Vivified platform ensures compliance with HIPAA regulations by providing structured logging utilities and auditing sensitive operations. This service is designed to log events with various levels of detail and supports future extensions to persist logs to an append-only store with specific retention policies.

## Features

- Structured logging for sensitive operations.
- Simple decorator for auditing actions.
- Support for various audit categories such as system, security, compliance, and user actions.
- Future support for append-only storage and data retention policies.

!!! note "HIPAA Compliance"
    The audit service is designed to comply with HIPAA regulations, ensuring that all logged data is handled securely and with the necessary retention policies.

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Audit Event] --> B{Audit Levels};
    B -->|Minimal| C[Log to Console];
    B -->|Standard| D[Log to File];
    B -->|Detailed| E[Send to Central Logging Service];
    B -->|Comprehensive| F[Persist to Audit Database];
```

## Security Considerations

!!! warning "Security"
    Ensure that all access to audit logs is restricted to authorized personnel only. Regular audits should be conducted to verify the integrity and security of the logged data.",

  "api": "# API Reference

The Audit Service does not expose a direct API for external use. Instead, it is integrated into the platform to automatically handle logging as per the predefined categories and levels.

### AuditCategory Enum

```python
from enum import Enum

class AuditCategory(str, Enum):
    SYSTEM = "system"
    SECURITY = "security"
    COMPLIANCE = "compliance"
    USER_ACTION = "user_action"
```

- **SYSTEM**: Logs related to system operations.
- **SECURITY**: Logs related to security events.
- **COMPLIANCE**: Logs ensuring compliance with legal requirements.
- **USER_ACTION**: Logs tracking user actions.",

  "config": "# Configuration Guide

The audit service configuration is defined within the codebase and can be adjusted as per the operational requirements.

## Configuration Options

| Option          | Description                      | Default Value |
|-----------------|----------------------------------|---------------|
| `AuditLevel`    | Level of detail for audit logs   | `MINIMAL`     |
| `RetentionPolicy` | Retention policy for audit logs | `None`        |

To change the configuration, update the `AuditLevel` within the `service.py` file:

```python
from .service import AuditLevel

current_audit_level = AuditLevel.STANDARD
```

!!! tip "Retention Policy"
    Implement a retention policy in later phases to ensure compliance with HIPAA's data retention requirements.",

  "examples": "# Usage Examples

The following examples demonstrate how to use the audit service in various scenarios.

## Logging an Audit Event

=== "Python"
    ```python
    from .service import AuditEvent, AuditCategory

    event = AuditEvent(
        event_type="access",
        category=AuditCategory.SECURITY,
        action="login_attempt",
        result="success",
        description="User login successful",
        user_id="user-123"
    )
    logger.info(json.dumps(event.__dict__))
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    curl -X POST \
        -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
        -d '{
            "event_type": "access",
            "category": "security",
            "action": "login_attempt",
            "result": "success",
            "description": "User login successful",
            "user_id": "user-123"
        }' \
        http://your-audit-service-endpoint/log
    ```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

- **Logs not being recorded**: Ensure the logger is correctly configured and the appropriate audit level is set.
- **Unauthorized access attempts**: Regularly review logs for any unauthorized access attempts, and ensure security protocols are enforced.

!!! note "Debug Mode"
    Enable debug mode in the logging configuration to capture more detailed logs during troubleshooting."
}

docs.title: Canonical
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Canonical Service Documentation

## Introduction
The **Canonical Service** is an integral component of the Vivified platform, designed to facilitate data normalization and ensure cross-plugin compatibility. This service is pivotal in maintaining consistent data formats across disparate systems, ensuring seamless integration and interoperability.

!!! note
    The Canonical Service is HIPAA-compliant, ensuring that all data transformations adhere to stringent privacy and security standards.

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Data Input] --> B[Canonical Service];
    B --> C[Data Transformer];
    C --> D[Canonical Models];
    C --> E[Schema Registry];
    E --> F[Schema Loader];
    D --> G[Output];
    F --> G;
```

## Key Components
- **Canonical Models**: Define the standard data structures for users, messages, and events.
- **Data Transformer**: Converts data between plugin-specific formats and canonical formats.
- **Schema Registry**: Manages versioned schemas, facilitating schema upgrades and compatibility.
- **Audit Service**: Logs and monitors data transformations to ensure compliance and traceability.

## Security Considerations
- **Data Encryption**: All data in transit and at rest is encrypted using industry-standard protocols.
- **Access Controls**: Strict access controls are enforced to ensure only authorized entities can perform data transformations.
- **Audit Logging**: Comprehensive logging of all data transformation activities for auditing and compliance verification.

!!! warning
    Ensure that all access to the Canonical Service is secured and monitored to prevent unauthorized data access.
",
  "api": "# API Reference

## CanonicalService Class

### Methods

#### `normalize_user`
Normalizes user data from one plugin format to another.

```python
async def normalize_user(
    self, user_data: Dict[str, Any], source_plugin: str, target_plugin: str
) -> CanonicalUser:
```

- **Parameters**:
  - `user_data`: Dictionary containing user information.
  - `source_plugin`: The source plugin format.
  - `target_plugin`: The target plugin format.

- **Returns**: A `CanonicalUser` object containing normalized user data.

## SchemaRegistry Class

### Methods

#### `upsert`
Inserts or updates a schema in the registry.

```python
def upsert(
    self, name: str, version: Version, schema_data: Dict[str, Any]
) -> None:
```

- **Parameters**:
  - `name`: The name of the schema.
  - `version`: The version of the schema.
  - `schema_data`: The schema data to be stored.

- **Returns**: None
",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

## Configuration Options

| Option              | Description                                      | Default        |
|---------------------|--------------------------------------------------|----------------|
| `audit_level`       | The level of auditing for data transformations. | `AuditLevel.BASIC` |
| `schema_directory`  | Directory path for storing schema files.        | `schemas/`     |

## Environment Variables

- `CANONICAL_CONFIG_PATH`: Path to the configuration file.
- `CANONICAL_LOG_LEVEL`: The logging level for the service.

!!! tip
    Ensure that configuration files are secured and only accessible to authorized personnel to maintain compliance.
",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

=== "Python"

    ```python
    from vivified.canonical.service import CanonicalService
    from vivified.audit.service import AuditService
    from vivified.policy.engine import PolicyEngine

    audit_service = AuditService()
    policy_engine = PolicyEngine()
    canonical_service = CanonicalService(audit_service, policy_engine)

    user_data = {
        'id': '1234',
        'username': 'jdoe',
        'email': 'jdoe@example.com'
    }

    normalized_user = await canonical_service.normalize_user(user_data, 'pluginA', 'pluginB')
    print(normalized_user)
    ```

=== "curl"

    ```bash
    curl -X POST https://api.vivified.com/canonical/normalize_user \
         -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
         -d '{
             "user_data": {
                 "id": "1234",
                 "username": "jdoe",
                 "email": "jdoe@example.com"
             },
             "source_plugin": "pluginA",
             "target_plugin": "pluginB"
         }'
    ```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

- **Issue**: Schema not found.
  - **Solution**: Ensure that the schema is correctly registered in the schema registry.

- **Issue**: Data transformation errors.
  - **Solution**: Check the input data format and ensure it matches the expected schema.

!!! note
    For persistent issues, consult the service logs and verify the configuration settings."
}

docs.title: Config
docs.text:
{
    "overview": "# Config Service Overview

The `config` service within the Vivified platform provides a robust solution for managing configuration data with an emphasis on security and compliance. This service supports hierarchical configuration management, encryption for sensitive data, and comprehensive audit logging, making it suitable for HIPAA-compliant environments.

!!! note
    This service is designed to ensure data integrity and confidentiality, crucial for environments that require strict compliance with regulations such as HIPAA.

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Client] -- Request --> B[Config Service]
    B -- Fetch/Store --> C[(Database)]
    B -- Encrypt/Decrypt --> D[Encryption Module]
```

## Key Components

- **Configuration Management**: Store and retrieve configuration settings.
- **Encryption**: Encrypt/decrypt sensitive configuration values using Fernet symmetric encryption.
- **Audit Logging**: Log configuration changes for auditing and compliance purposes.",
    "api": "# Config Service API Reference

The Config Service API provides endpoints for managing configuration settings. Below are the available operations:

!!! tip
    Use the API to programmatically manage configuration settings, ensuring automated processes can integrate with the config service.

## Endpoints

Currently, there is no direct API documentation provided. Integration with this service occurs through the `ConfigService` class in the Python code.

=== "Python"
    ```python
    from config_service import ConfigService
    
    service = ConfigService(db_session=my_session, encryption_key=my_key)
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    # No direct HTTP API available, use Python client
    ```

For more detailed usage, refer to the `service.py` file and its class methods.",
    "config": "# Configuration Guide

The configuration system supports various options and settings. Below is a data table listing the configuration options:

| Option        | Description                               | Type     | Required | Default    |
|---------------|-------------------------------------------|----------|----------|------------|
| `encryption_key` | Key for encrypting sensitive information | `string` | Yes      | N/A        |
| `db_session`  | Database session for persistence          | `object` | Yes      | N/A        |

!!! warning
    Ensure the `encryption_key` is securely stored and managed. Loss of the key will make it impossible to decrypt sensitive configuration data.

## Security Considerations

- **Encryption**: Sensitive data is encrypted using Fernet symmetric encryption. Ensure that the encryption key is rotated periodically and stored securely.
- **Access Controls**: Limit access to configuration management to authorized personnel only.
- **Audit Logging**: Enable logging to track access and changes to configuration data.",
    "examples": "# Usage Examples

Below are examples of using the Config Service to manage configuration settings.

=== "Python"
    ```python
    from config_service import ConfigService
    from sqlalchemy.ext.asyncio import AsyncSession

    # Initialize service
    session = AsyncSession()
    service = ConfigService(db_session=session, encryption_key="my_secure_key")

    # Set a configuration item
    service.set_config("api_key", "12345", is_sensitive=True)

    # Get a configuration item
    api_key = service.get_config("api_key")
    print(api_key)
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    # No direct curl example available
    # Use the Python client to interact with the service
    ```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

- **Unable to Decrypt Data**: Ensure that the correct encryption key is being used. Verify that the environment variable `CONFIG_ENC_KEY` is set correctly if using environment-based keys.
- **Database Connectivity**: Check database connection settings and ensure the database is reachable.

!!! tip
    Always verify that the encryption key and database credentials are correctly configured to prevent runtime issues."
}

docs.title: Gateway
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Gateway Service Documentation

The **Gateway Service** serves as a critical component in the Vivified platform, providing secure external API access and proxy functionality. This service is designed to ensure compliance with HIPAA regulations while offering robust security features such as rate limiting and domain allowlisting.

!!! note
    The Gateway Service is a HIPAA-compliant service, ensuring that all external communications adhere to the necessary privacy and security standards.

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Client Request] -->|HTTP Method| B[Gateway Service]
    B -->|Proxy Request| C[External API]
    B -->|Audit Logs| D[Audit Service]
    B -->|Policy Decision| E[Policy Engine]
```

## Key Components
- **ProxyHandler**: Manages external API requests with security checks and rate limiting.
- **AuditService**: Logs all actions for compliance and monitoring.
- **PolicyEngine**: Evaluates requests against predefined security policies.
- **DomainAllowlist**: Controls which domains are accessible through the gateway.

## Security Considerations
- All requests are logged and monitored by the `AuditService` to ensure compliance.
- The `PolicyEngine` enforces security policies on every request.
- Rate limiting is implemented to prevent abuse and ensure fair usage.

!!! warning
    Ensure that all configurations comply with HIPAA rules to maintain data privacy and security.",
  "api": "# API Reference

The Gateway Service provides an API for managing proxy requests.

## ProxyRequest

| Field      | Type          | Description                                  |
|------------|---------------|----------------------------------------------|
| `id`       | `str`         | Unique identifier for the request.           |
| `plugin_id`| `str`         | Identifier for the plugin making the request.|
| `method`   | `ProxyMethod` | HTTP method (GET, POST, etc.).               |
| `url`      | `HttpUrl`     | Target URL for the request.                  |
| `headers`  | `Dict[str,str]`| Custom headers to include in the request.   |
| `body`     | `Optional[bytes]`| Payload for the request.                   |
| `timeout`  | `int`         | Request timeout in seconds.                  |
| `retries`  | `int`         | Number of retry attempts.                    |

## ProxyMethod

| Method     | Description                        |
|------------|------------------------------------|
| `GET`      | Retrieve data from the server.     |
| `POST`     | Send data to the server.           |
| `PUT`      | Update data on the server.         |
| `DELETE`   | Remove data from the server.       |
| `PATCH`    | Partial update of data on the server. |
| `HEAD`     | Retrieve headers from the server.  |
| `OPTIONS`  | Describe communication options.    |",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

The Gateway Service can be configured using various parameters to control its behavior and ensure compliance.

| Parameter          | Type      | Default | Description                                    |
|--------------------|-----------|---------|------------------------------------------------|
| `audit_service`    | `AuditService` | N/A     | Service for logging and monitoring.            |
| `policy_engine`    | `PolicyEngine` | N/A     | Service for evaluating security policies.     |
| `config_service`   | `Any`     | `None`  | Optional service for additional configurations.|

!!! tip
    Customize the `DomainAllowlist` to restrict access to specific domains.

### Rate Limiting

The Gateway Service implements rate limiting to manage request throughput and ensure compliance with HIPAA regulations.

```yaml
rate_limits:
  default:
    requests_per_minute: 60
    burst_capacity: 10
```

### Domain Allowlisting

```yaml
domain_allowlists:
  - domain: "api.example.com"
    allow: true
  - domain: "*.trusted.com"
    allow: true
```

!!! note
    Ensure that the domains listed in `DomainAllowlist` comply with HIPAA privacy rules.",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

=== "Python"
    ```python
    from vivified.gateway.service import GatewayService
    from vivified.audit.service import AuditService
    from vivified.policy.engine import PolicyEngine

    # Initialize services
    audit_service = AuditService()
    policy_engine = PolicyEngine()

    # Create gateway service
    gateway_service = GatewayService(audit_service, policy_engine)
    
    # Make a proxy request
    proxy_request = ProxyRequest(
        plugin_id="plugin123",
        method=ProxyMethod.GET,
        url="https://api.example.com/data"
    )
    response = gateway_service.proxy_handler.handle_request(proxy_request)
    print(response)
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    curl -X GET "https://api.example.com/data" \
         -H "Authorization: Bearer <token>" \
         -H "Content-Type: application/json"
    ```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

- **Timeout Errors**: Ensure the `timeout` parameter is set appropriately for long-running requests.
- **Blocked Domains**: Verify that the target domain is included in the `DomainAllowlist`.

### Debugging Steps

1. Check the audit logs for any recorded errors.
2. Verify the policy decisions using the `PolicyEngine` logs.
3. Ensure rate limits are properly configured and being adhered to.

!!! warning
    Unauthorized attempts to access restricted domains will be logged and could result in service denial as part of security enforcement."
}

docs.title: Identity & Auth
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Identity Service Documentation

The **identity** service is a critical component of the Vivified platform, responsible for user authentication and identity management. This service is designed to be secure, scalable, and HIPAA-compliant, ensuring that sensitive information is protected according to regulatory standards.

## Key Features
- JWT-based authentication
- Role-based access control
- Multi-factor authentication (MFA)

!!! note
    This service is part of the Vivified Phase 2 deployment and includes FastAPI dependencies to protect endpoints.

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[User] -->|Requests Access| B[Identity Service];
    B -->|Validates Credentials| C[JWT Token];
    C -->|Returned to| A;
    A -->|Uses JWT| D[Protected Resource];
```

## Security Considerations
- Ensure that all JWT tokens are signed with a secure algorithm.
- Regularly rotate encryption keys and secrets.
- Implement MFA for enhanced security.

!!! warning
    Never expose JWT tokens or secrets in client-side code.

## Troubleshooting

1. **Issue**: Users cannot log in.
   - **Solution**: Verify if the user account is active and the password is correct.

2. **Issue**: JWT token expiration issues.
   - **Solution**: Check server time synchronization and token expiration settings.

3. **Issue**: MFA not working as expected.
   - **Solution**: Ensure the MFA secret is correctly configured in the user profile.
",
  "api": "# API Reference

## Endpoints

### Authentication

- **POST /auth/login**
  - Description: Authenticate a user and return a JWT token.
  - Request Body:
    ```json
    {
      "username": "string",
      "password": "string"
    }
    ```
  - Response:
    ```json
    {
      "token": "string"
    }
    ```

- **GET /auth/validate**
  - Description: Validate a provided JWT token.
  - Request Header:
    ```
    Authorization: Bearer <token>
    ```
  - Response:
    ```json
    {
      "valid": true
    }
    ```

## Models

### User
- **Fields**:
  - `id`: UUID
  - `username`: string
  - `email`: string
  - `password_hash`: string
  - `mfa_enabled`: boolean
  - `is_active`: boolean
",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

## Environment Variables

| Variable Name        | Description                     | Default Value |
|----------------------|---------------------------------|---------------|
| `JWT_SECRET`         | Secret key for JWT signing      | `change_me`   |
| `JWT_ALGORITHM`      | Algorithm for JWT signing       | `HS256`       |
| `DB_CONNECTION`      | Database connection string      | `postgresql://user:pass@localhost/db` |
| `MFA_REQUIRED`       | Enforce MFA for all users       | `false`       |

!!! tip
    Ensure all environment variables are set in a secure manner and not hard-coded in your application code.
",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

=== "Python"

    ```python
    import requests

    response = requests.post('https://api.vivified.com/auth/login', json={
        'username': 'user@example.com',
        'password': 'securepassword'
    })
    token = response.json()['token']
    headers = {'Authorization': f'Bearer {token}'}
    validation_response = requests.get('https://api.vivified.com/auth/validate', headers=headers)
    print(validation_response.json())
    ```

=== "curl"

    ```bash
    curl -X POST https://api.vivified.com/auth/login \
         -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
         -d '{"username": "user@example.com", "password": "securepassword"}'

    token="<JWT_TOKEN>"

    curl -X GET https://api.vivified.com/auth/validate \
         -H "Authorization: Bearer $token"
    ```
"
}

docs.title: Messaging
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "## Messaging Service Overview

The messaging service is an integral component of the Vivified platform that facilitates inter-plugin communication with strict adherence to HIPAA compliance. It ensures secure and efficient data exchange across various platform modules.

!!! note
    This service uses a canonical message format and supports multiple message types, including events, requests, responses, and notifications.

### Architecture

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Messaging Service] -->|Sends Message| B[Event Bus];
    B --> C{Broker}
    C -->|Dispatch| D[Subscriber Plugins];
    C -->|Audit| E[Audit Service];
    C -->|Policy Check| F[Policy Engine];
```

### Key Components
- **MessagingService**: The main service managing message dispatch and receipt.
- **EventBus**: Abstracts the broker for message publishing and subscribing, supporting various backends like NATS, Redis, or in-memory.
- **AuditService**: Ensures all message interactions are logged for compliance and security auditing.
- **PolicyEngine**: Evaluates policies to enforce data privacy and security measures.

### Security Considerations
- All messages are audited to ensure compliance with HIPAA regulations.
- Data classifications such as PHI and PII are enforced to protect sensitive information.
- The policy engine ensures that all data exchanges comply with predefined security policies.

!!! warning
    Ensure that the messaging service is deployed in a secure and isolated environment to prevent unauthorized access to sensitive data.

## Troubleshooting

1. **Message Delivery Failures**
   - Check network connectivity and broker availability.
   - Ensure correct broker configuration in the environment settings.

2. **Policy Decision Denials**
   - Review policy rules in the PolicyEngine for accuracy and relevancy.
   - Validate user permissions and roles against policy requirements.",
  "api": "## Messaging Service API Reference

### MessagingService

- `__init__(self, audit_service: AuditService, policy_engine: PolicyEngine)`: Initializes the messaging service with audit and policy components.
- `start(self)`: Starts the messaging service for handling inter-plugin communication.

### Message Model

| Attribute        | Type               | Description                         |
|------------------|--------------------|-------------------------------------|
| `id`             | `str`              | Unique identifier for the message.  |
| `message_type`   | `MessageType`      | Type of the message (e.g., event).  |
| `priority`       | `MessagePriority`  | Priority level of the message.      |

### MessageType Enum
- `EVENT`: Represents an event message.
- `REQUEST`: Represents a request message.
- `RESPONSE`: Represents a response message.
- `NOTIFICATION`: Represents a notification message.

### MessagePriority Enum
- `LOW`, `NORMAL`, `HIGH`, `CRITICAL`: Priority levels.

### DataClassification Enum
- `PUBLIC`, `INTERNAL`, `CONFIDENTIAL`, `PHI`, `PII`: Data classification levels.",
  "config": "## Configuration Guide

The messaging service can be configured using environment variables or configuration files. Below are the key configuration options:

| Option                  | Description                                        | Default        |
|-------------------------|----------------------------------------------------|----------------|
| `EVENT_BUS_BACKEND`     | Backend for the event bus (`nats`, `redis`, `memory`). | `memory`       |
| `LOG_LEVEL`             | Logging level for the service (`DEBUG`, `INFO`).   | `INFO`         |

To configure the event bus backend to use Redis, set the environment variable:

```bash
export EVENT_BUS_BACKEND=redis
```

!!! tip
    Test your configuration changes in a development environment before applying them to production.",
  "examples": "## Usage Examples

=== "Python"

    ```python
    from vivified.messaging.service import MessagingService
    from vivified.audit.service import AuditService
    from vivified.policy.engine import PolicyEngine

    audit_service = AuditService()
    policy_engine = PolicyEngine()
    messaging_service = MessagingService(audit_service, policy_engine)

    async def start_service():
        await messaging_service.start()
    ```

=== "curl"

    ```bash
    # Example command to check service status
    curl -X GET http://localhost:8000/status
    ```

These examples demonstrate how to initialize and start the messaging service using Python and how to interact with it via command-line tools like curl."
}

docs.title: Monitoring
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Monitoring Service Documentation

## Overview

The **Monitoring Service** for the Vivified platform is designed to provide real-time metrics and monitoring capabilities to ensure system reliability and compliance with HIPAA regulations. This service collects, aggregates, and exposes metrics using Prometheus, making it easier to monitor the health and performance of the platform.

!!! note
    This service is compliant with HIPAA regulations, ensuring that all monitoring activities respect the privacy and security of protected health information (PHI).

## Architecture

The Monitoring Service is built using the FastAPI framework and integrates with Prometheus for metrics collection.

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[User Request] -->|API Call| B[FastAPI Application];
    B --> C{Metrics Collection};
    C -->|Record Duration| D[Histogram: request_duration];
    C -->|Track Plugins| E[Gauge: active_plugins];
    C -->|Count Notifications| F[Counter: notifications_sends_total];
    C -->|Count Sent Notifications| G[Counter: notifications_sent_total];
    C -->|Count Failed Notifications| H[Counter: notifications_failed_total];
    D -->|Expose Metrics| I[Prometheus];
    E --> I;
    F --> I;
    G --> I;
    H --> I;
```

## Security Considerations

!!! warning
    Ensure that the monitoring endpoints are secured and accessible only to authorized personnel. Exposing these endpoints publicly could lead to unauthorized access to sensitive operational data.

- **Encryption**: All data in transit should be encrypted using TLS to prevent interception.
- **Authentication**: Implement authentication mechanisms to restrict access to metrics.
- **Audit Logs**: Maintain logs of who accesses the metrics and when, to comply with HIPAA auditing requirements.",
  "api": "# API Reference

## Endpoints

### `/metrics`

This endpoint exposes all collected metrics in a format compatible with Prometheus.

!!! tip
    Use authentication headers to access this endpoint securely.

=== "Python"

    ```python
    import requests

    response = requests.get('https://your-domain.com/metrics', headers={'Authorization': 'Bearer YOUR_TOKEN'})
    print(response.text)
    ```

=== "curl"

    ```bash
    curl -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_TOKEN" https://your-domain.com/metrics
    ```

## Metrics Details

- **`vivified_request_duration_seconds`**: Histogram tracking the duration of requests.
- **`vivified_active_plugins`**: Gauge showing the number of active plugins.
- **`vivified_notifications_sends_total`**: Counter for total notification requests received.
- **`vivified_notifications_sent_total`**: Counter for notifications marked sent.
- **`vivified_notifications_failed_total`**: Counter for notifications marked as failed.",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

## Configuration Options

| Option                   | Description                          | Default |
|--------------------------|--------------------------------------|---------|
| `PROMETHEUS_ENDPOINT`    | URL for accessing Prometheus metrics | `/metrics`|
| `AUTH_TOKEN`             | Token for securing the metrics endpoint | None    |
| `ENABLE_TLS`             | Boolean to enable/disable TLS        | `True`  |

!!! note
    Ensure that the `PROMETHEUS_ENDPOINT` is secured and not exposed to unauthorized users.",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

## Collecting Metrics

To collect metrics from the Monitoring Service, you can use the following examples:

=== "Python"

    ```python
    import requests

    def fetch_metrics():
        url = 'https://your-domain.com/metrics'
        headers = {'Authorization': 'Bearer YOUR_TOKEN'}
        response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
        if response.status_code == 200:
            return response.text
        else:
            raise Exception('Failed to fetch metrics')
    ```

=== "curl"

    ```bash
    curl -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_TOKEN" https://your-domain.com/metrics
    ```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

- **Unauthorized Access**
  - Ensure your `AUTH_TOKEN` is correctly configured and passed in the request header.
  - Verify that the endpoint is not publicly accessible without proper authentication.

- **Metrics Not Updating**
  - Check the application logs for any errors in metrics collection.
  - Ensure that the Prometheus server is correctly scraping the `/metrics` endpoint.

!!! tip
    Regularly audit your configurations and access logs to maintain HIPAA compliance."
}

docs.title: Notifications
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Notifications Service Documentation

The **notifications** service in the Vivified platform is designed to manage and dispatch notifications while ensuring compliance with HIPAA standards. This service is crucial for maintaining communication within the platform, orchestrating notifications, and managing the lifecycle of notification events.

## Key Responsibilities

- **Accept Notification Requests**: The service accepts requests to send notifications and publishes canonical events for further processing.
- **Subscribe and Manage Events**: It subscribes to `NotificationSent` events and maintains an inbox.
- **Expose Settings**: Provides simple settings that are currently in-memory but are designed to be pluggable with Redis/Postgres in the future.
- **Metrics and Auditing**: Emits Prometheus metrics for monitoring and audit events for compliance and traceability.

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[NotificationRequest] -->|Publish Event| B[MessagingService];
    B --> C[PolicyEngine];
    C --> D[AuditService];
    B --> E[NotificationSent Event];
    E --> F[InboxItem Management];
    D --> G[Prometheus Metrics];
```

!!! note
    This service is a proof of concept and currently uses in-memory storage for settings and inbox items. Future enhancements will include integration with Redis or Postgres.
",
  "api": "# API Reference

The notifications service currently does not expose a REST API directly but interacts through event-driven mechanisms and internal service calls. Below are the primary data models utilized:

## NotificationRequest
- `notification_id`: Unique identifier for the notification.
- `title`: Optional title of the notification.
- `body`: Main content of the notification.
- `priority`: Priority level of the notification (`low`, `normal`, `high`, `critical`).
- `channel`: Optional communication channel.
- `targets`: List of target recipients.
- `metadata`: Additional metadata.

## NotificationSent
- `event_type`: Type of the event, default is `NotificationSent`.
- `notification_id`: Identifier for the sent notification.
- `plugin`: The plugin used to send the notification.
- `timestamp`: Time the notification was sent.
- `status`: Current status of the notification (`queued`, `sent`, `partial`, `failed`).
- `details`: Additional details about the notification event.

## Example Event Subscription
=== "Python"
    ```python
    from core.messaging.service import MessagingService
    
    def handle_notification_sent(event):
        # Process notification sent event
        print(f"Notification {event.notification_id} sent with status {event.status}")
    
    messaging_service = MessagingService()
    messaging_service.subscribe("NotificationSent", handle_notification_sent)
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    curl -X POST \
      http://localhost:8080/events/subscribe \
      -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
      -d '{"event_type": "NotificationSent", "callback_url": "http://myservice/handle"}'
    ```
",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

The following table outlines the configuration options available for the notifications service:

| Configuration Option     | Description                                      | Default Value |
|--------------------------|--------------------------------------------------|---------------|
| `inbox_storage`          | Determines the type of storage for the inbox     | `in-memory`   |
| `metrics_enabled`        | Enables or disables Prometheus metrics emission  | `true`        |
| `audit_level`            | Sets the level of audit logging                  | `normal`      |
| `default_notification_channel` | Default channel for sending notifications | `email`       |

!!! warning
    Ensure that configuration changes adhere to HIPAA compliance standards, especially when dealing with sensitive data.

## Security Considerations

- **Data Encryption**: All notifications containing PHI (Protected Health Information) must be encrypted in transit and at rest.
- **Access Control**: Ensure that only authorized personnel have access to the configuration and the ability to send notifications.
- **Audit Logs**: Maintain comprehensive audit logs of all notification events to comply with HIPAA regulations.
",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

## Sending a Notification

=== "Python"
```python
from core.messaging.service import MessagingService
from .models import NotificationRequest, NotificationPriority

# Create a notification request
notification = NotificationRequest(
    notification_id="12345",
    title="Urgent Update",
    body="Please review the latest policy changes.",
    priority=NotificationPriority.high,
    targets=["user1@example.com", "user2@example.com"]
)

# Send the notification
messaging_service = MessagingService()
messaging_service.publish_event("NotificationRequest", notification.dict())
```

=== "curl"
```bash
curl -X POST \
  http://localhost:8080/notifications/send \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
        "notification_id": "12345",
        "title": "Urgent Update",
        "body": "Please review the latest policy changes.",
        "priority": "high",
        "targets": ["user1@example.com", "user2@example.com"]
      }'
```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

1. **Notifications not being sent**
   - Verify if the messaging service is correctly configured and active.
   - Check logs for any errors related to policy engine decisions.

2. **High latency in notification delivery**
   - Review Prometheus metrics to identify bottlenecks.
   - Consider increasing resources or optimizing the notification processing logic.

### Logs and Debugging

- Check the logs generated by the AuditService for any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts.

!!! tip
    Regularly review and optimize the notification processing logic to handle high loads efficiently and maintain HIPAA compliance."
}

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
• :material-shield-check:{ .lg .middle } Core Services

    Canonical, Storage, Messaging, Gateway — secure and modular

  • :material-puzzle:{ .lg .middle } Modular Design

    Plugin-first architecture with well-defined contracts

  • :material-insights:{ .lg .middle } Observability

    Audit logs, metrics, and health endpoints across services

Admin-First Design

All core service operations must be available through the Admin Console. No CLI-only controls.

PHI/PII Handling

Core services are built to minimize PHI exposure. Use classification and redaction in storage and messages.

Network Exposure

Do not expose internal core endpoints directly to the public internet. Use the Gateway for external access.

docs.title: Services at a Glance
docs.text:
Service Purpose Exposed Interfaces HIPAA canonical Normalize and transform data gRPC/REST, plugins Compliant storage Encrypted PHI/PII storage REST API, SDK Compliant messaging Inter-plugin event bus Pub/Sub API Compliant gateway External proxy & filtering HTTP(S) ingress Compliant

  • :material-code-tags-check:{ .lg .middle } Stable SDKs

    Python and Node.js SDKs for service access

  • :material-security:{ .lg .middle } Audit & Retention

    7-year retention for audit logs, tamper-proof append-only store

docs.title: High-level Architecture
docs.text: mermaid flowchart LR AdminUI[Admin Console] -->|Admin API| API[Admin API Gateway] API --> Canonical[Canonical Service] API --> Storage[Storage Service] API --> Messaging[Messaging Service] Gateway[External Gateway] -->|Proxied Requests| API Storage -->|Encrypted| Vault[(Key Vault)]

docs.title: Getting Service Status
docs.text:
PythonNode.jscurl 
# (1) Simple health check against Admin API
import requests
r = requests.get('https://localhost:8443/health')
print(r.json())

// (1) Node health check
const fetch = require('node-fetch')
fetch('https://localhost:8443/health').then(r => r.json()).then(console.log)

# (1) Use curl to check overall platform health
curl -sS https://localhost:8443/health | jq
  1. Requests the unified health endpoint which aggregates service health

docs.title: Service Contracts (short)
docs.text:
• Canonical: accepts plugin-specific payloads, returns normalized canonical model
  • Storage: uses AES-256 at rest, per-tenant keying supported
  • Messaging: event bus supports routing, filters, and PII-safe payloads
  • Gateway: domain allowlists, request/response transformations

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: CanonicalUser Standard user model across plugins Audit Log Immutable, append-only record of data and operational events

docs.title: Operational Checklist
docs.text:
• Ensure audit.retention_years >= 7
  • Verify encryption keys stored in Key Vault
  • Regularly rotate keys and review RBAC
Debugging Tips

Use Ctrl+Shift+I to open browser devtools for Admin UI troubleshooting. Check network requests to /api/* endpoints.

docs.title: Plugin manager
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Plugin Manager Service

The `plugin_manager` service within the Vivified platform is a critical component responsible for managing the lifecycle of plugins. This service ensures plugins are registered, secure, and healthy, aligning with HIPAA compliance requirements. It provides enhanced functionality through security validation and health monitoring.

## Key Features

- **Security Validation:** Ensures plugins meet stringent security configurations.
- **Health Monitoring:** Regularly checks the health of plugins and initiates recovery if necessary.
- **Lifecycle Management:** Handles registration, activation, and deactivation of plugins.

!!! note
    The `plugin_manager` service is designed to integrate seamlessly with other components of the Vivified platform, ensuring consistent and secure plugin operations.

## Architecture Overview

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Plugin Registration] --> B[Security Validation];
    B --> C[Health Monitoring];
    C --> D[Lifecycle Management];
    B --> E{Compliance Check};
    E -->|Pass| F[Activate Plugin];
    E -->|Fail| G[Notify Admin];
    D --> H[Audit Logging];
```

This diagram illustrates the flow from plugin registration through security validation and health monitoring, ensuring compliance and operational integrity.",
  "api": "# API Reference

## Plugin Registration Endpoint

The plugin manager provides a RESTful API for plugin registration.

### Endpoint: `/register`

- **Method:** POST
- **Description:** Registers a new plugin with the platform.

#### Request Parameters

| Parameter | Type   | Description                |
|-----------|--------|----------------------------|
| manifest  | JSON   | Plugin manifest details    |

#### Responses

- **200 OK:** Plugin registered successfully.
- **400 Bad Request:** Invalid manifest data.

!!! tip
    Ensure the plugin manifest includes all required fields and adheres to the security configurations specified in the platform policies.",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

## SecurityValidator Configuration

The `SecurityValidator` class ensures plugins conform to security policies.

### Security Configurations

| Configuration           | Description                                          |
|-------------------------|------------------------------------------------------|
| authentication_required | Ensures the plugin requires authentication           |
| network_isolation       | Ensures the plugin operates in an isolated network   |
| data_classification     | Ensures the plugin data is classified appropriately  |

!!! warning
    Plugins must not have any blocked domains or dangerous traits as per the security policies.

## HealthMonitor Configuration

| Configuration      | Description                                           |
|--------------------|-------------------------------------------------------|
| check_interval     | Interval (seconds) between health checks              |
| failure_threshold  | Number of consecutive failures before marking unhealthy |

These configurations ensure the continuous monitoring and health of plugins.",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

## Registering a Plugin

Use the following examples to register a plugin with the Vivified platform.

=== "Python"

```python
import requests

manifest = {
    "id": "plugin-123",
    "name": "Example Plugin",
    "version": "1.0.0",
    "description": "A sample plugin",
    "contracts": [],
    "traits": ["hipaa_authorized"],
    "dependencies": [],
    "allowed_domains": ["example.com"],
    "security": {
        "authentication_required": True,
        "network_isolation": True,
        "data_classification": "confidential"
    }
}

response = requests.post("https://vivified-platform/api/register", json=manifest)
print(response.status_code)
```

=== "curl"

```bash
curl -X POST https://vivified-platform/api/register \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    -d '{
        "id": "plugin-123",
        "name": "Example Plugin",
        "version": "1.0.0",
        "description": "A sample plugin",
        "contracts": [],
        "traits": ["hipaa_authorized"],
        "dependencies": [],
        "allowed_domains": ["example.com"],
        "security": {
            "authentication_required": true,
            "network_isolation": true,
            "data_classification": "confidential"
        }
    }'
```

These examples demonstrate how to register a plugin with the required security attributes.",
  "security_considerations": "# Security Considerations

The `plugin_manager` service incorporates several security measures to ensure HIPAA compliance:

- **Blocked Domains:** Utilizes a list of blocked domains to prevent unauthorized access.
- **Dangerous Traits:** Identifies and restricts plugins with traits such as `admin`, `system`, or `root`.
- **PHI Handling:** Ensures all plugins handling Protected Health Information (PHI) are properly authorized and audited.

!!! important
    Always verify the security configurations of a plugin before registration to ensure it adheres to HIPAA and organizational policies.",
  "troubleshooting": "# Troubleshooting

## Common Issues

### Plugin Registration Fails

- **Cause:** Invalid or incomplete manifest data.
- **Solution:** Verify all required fields in the manifest are provided and correctly formatted.

### Security Validation Errors

- **Cause:** Plugin contains blocked domains or unauthorized traits.
- **Solution:** Review the security policies and adjust the plugin configuration accordingly.

### Health Monitoring Alerts

- **Cause:** Plugin is marked as unhealthy due to consecutive failures.
- **Solution:** Investigate plugin logs for errors and ensure network connectivity and resource availability.

!!! note
    For persistent issues, consult the platform's audit logs and reach out to the support team with detailed error messages for further assistance."
}

docs.title: Policy Engine
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Policy Service Overview

The **Policy Service** in the Vivified platform is designed to provide a robust, trait-based policy engine that enforces hierarchical access control, data classification, and plugin interaction policies. This service plays a critical role in maintaining compliance with HIPAA regulations by ensuring that access to sensitive data is closely monitored and controlled.

!!! note
    The Policy Service is an integral part of the Vivified platform's security infrastructure, providing fine-grained access control and data protection.

## Key Features
- **Hierarchical Trait-Based Access Control**: Enforces access policies based on user roles and capabilities.
- **Data Classification Enforcement**: Ensures compliance with data access policies.
- **Plugin Interaction Policies**: Manages how plugins can interact with the system.
- **UI Feature Gating**: Controls access to specific UI features based on user roles.
- **Comprehensive Audit Logging**: Logs all policy decisions for audit and compliance purposes.

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Policy Request] -->|Evaluates| B[Policy Engine]
    B -->|Decision| C[Policy Decision]
    B -->|Logs| D[Audit Log]
    B -->|Enforces| E[Data Classification]
    B -->|Controls| F[UI Features]
```

## Security Considerations
The Policy Service is designed with security at its core, aligning with HIPAA requirements:

- **Audit Logging**: Every decision made by the policy engine is logged for audit purposes.
- **Access Control**: Implements strict access control measures to prevent unauthorized data access.
- **Data Sanitization**: Provides mechanisms to sanitize sensitive data before exposure.

!!! warning
    Ensure that all API requests to the Policy Service are authenticated and encrypted to prevent unauthorized access or data breaches.

## Troubleshooting

If you encounter issues with the Policy Service:

- **Check Logs**: Review the audit logs to identify any unauthorized access attempts or errors in policy evaluation.
- **Verify Configuration**: Ensure that the trait registry and policy configurations are correctly set up and loaded.

!!! tip
    Regularly update the trait definitions and policy rules to adapt to new security requirements and compliance regulations.
",
  "api": "# Policy API Reference

The Policy Service API provides endpoints for evaluating access control policies and managing trait-based rules.

## Endpoints

### Evaluate Policy
- **Endpoint**: `/api/policy/evaluate`
- **Method**: `POST`
- **Description**: Evaluates a policy request based on provided traits and context.

#### Request Parameters

| Parameter | Type   | Description |
|-----------|--------|-------------|
| `user_id` | string | Unique identifier for the user making the request. |
| `context` | string | Context for policy evaluation (e.g., `USER_ACTION`). |
| `traits`  | list   | List of traits associated with the request. |

#### Response

- **200 OK**: Returns the policy decision (`allow`, `deny`, `sanitize`).

!!! example "Python"
    ```python
    import requests
    response = requests.post('https://api.vivified.com/policy/evaluate', json={
        'user_id': '12345',
        'context': 'USER_ACTION',
        'traits': ['role:admin', 'capability:read']
    })
    print(response.json())
    ```

!!! example "curl"
    ```bash
    curl -X POST https://api.vivified.com/policy/evaluate \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    -d '{"user_id": "12345", "context": "USER_ACTION", "traits": ["role:admin", "capability:read"]}'
    ```
",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

The Policy Service configuration involves setting up the trait registry and defining policy rules.

## Trait Registry

The trait registry classifies and validates traits used in policy evaluation.

| Option          | Description                                |
|-----------------|--------------------------------------------|
| `ROLE`          | Defines user roles and permissions.        |
| `CAPABILITY`    | Specifies user or plugin capabilities.     |
| `DATA_ACCESS`   | Manages access to classified data.         |
| `UI_FEATURE`    | Controls UI elements and feature access.   |
| `PLUGIN_TYPE`   | Categorizes plugins for interaction policies. |
| `SECURITY`      | Security-related traits and enforcement.   |
| `COMPLIANCE`    | Compliance requirements for data access.   |

## Policy Rules

Define rules based on traits to enforce access control and data compliance.

- **Rule Format**: JSON objects specifying trait conditions and resulting policy decisions.

## Logging Configuration

Ensure logging is enabled to maintain an audit trail of policy decisions.

```yaml
logging:
  level: DEBUG
  handlers: [console, file]
```

!!! note
    Regularly review and update the trait registry and policy rules to maintain compliance with evolving regulations.
",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

## Evaluating Policy Requests

The following examples demonstrate how to evaluate policy requests using the Policy Service API.

=== "Python"
    ```python
    import requests
    
    def evaluate_policy(user_id, context, traits):
        url = 'https://api.vivified.com/policy/evaluate'
        payload = {
            'user_id': user_id,
            'context': context,
            'traits': traits
        }
        response = requests.post(url, json=payload)
        return response.json()

    decision = evaluate_policy('12345', 'USER_ACTION', ['role:admin', 'data_access:confidential'])
    print('Policy Decision:', decision)
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    curl -X POST https://api.vivified.com/policy/evaluate \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    -d '{"user_id": "12345", "context": "USER_ACTION", "traits": ["role:admin", "data_access:confidential"]}'
    ```

!!! tip
    Use the `SANITIZE` decision to allow access while ensuring sensitive data is removed from responses.
"
}

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "# Security Service Documentation

## Overview
The **Security Service** in the Vivified platform provides robust mechanisms to ensure data confidentiality, integrity, and compliance with HIPAA regulations. It encompasses TLS configuration for secure communications and encryption utilities for protecting sensitive data such as PHI and PII.

!!! note
    The security service is designed to be HIPAA-compliant, ensuring that all data transactions and storage adhere to stringent security requirements.

## Architecture
The security service consists of two main components:

- **TLS Configuration**: Establishes secure communication channels using SSL/TLS protocols.
- **Encryption Utilities**: Provides encryption and decryption functionalities for sensitive data.

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[TLS Configuration] --> B[SSL Context Creation];
    C[Encryption Utilities] --> D[AES-256-GCM Encryption];
    D --> E[Data Protection];
```

",
  "api": "# API Reference

## TLS Configuration
The TLS configuration is handled via the `tls_config.py` file, which creates a secure SSL context for server communications.

## Encryption Utilities
The `encryption.py` file provides an API for encrypting and decrypting data using AES-256-GCM.

### Methods

- `create_tls_context(cert_dir: str) -> ssl.SSLContext`: Creates and returns an SSL context configured with the specified certificates.
- `HIPAAEncryption.encrypt(data: Dict, associated_data: str) -> Tuple[str, str]`: Encrypts data with associated data for context.
- `HIPAAEncryption.decrypt(ciphertext: str, associated_data: str) -> Dict`: Decrypts data using the associated context data.

",
  "config": "# Configuration Guide

## TLS Configuration
The TLS setup is critical for secure communication between clients and servers. The `tls_config.py` file includes the following configuration options:

| Option       | Description                                |
|--------------|--------------------------------------------|
| cert_dir     | Directory path for certificate files       |
| ca_cert      | Path to the CA certificate file            |
| server_cert  | Path to the server certificate file        |
| server_key   | Path to the server key file                |

!!! warning
    Ensure that the certificate and key files are kept secure and only accessible by authorized personnel.

## Encryption Configuration
The encryption utilities use AES-256-GCM for data encryption. Ensure that:

- Keys are securely stored and managed.
- Key rotation policies are implemented using a KMS or HSM for long-term storage.

!!! tip
    Regularly update and rotate encryption keys to maintain security.

",
  "examples": "# Usage Examples

## TLS Context Creation
The following example demonstrates how to create an SSL context for secure communications:

=== "Python"
    ```python
    from tls_config import create_tls_context
    context = create_tls_context(cert_dir="/path/to/certs")
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    curl --cert /path/to/core.crt --key /path/to/core.key https://secure.example.com
    ```

## Data Encryption and Decryption

=== "Python"
    ```python
    from encryption import HIPAAEncryption

    data = {"patient_id": "12345", "data": "sensitive information"}
    encryption_instance = HIPAAEncryption()
    ciphertext, tag = encryption_instance.encrypt(data, "12345")
    decrypted_data = encryption_instance.decrypt(ciphertext, "12345")
    ```

## Security Considerations
- Ensure all data is transmitted over secure channels.
- Use strong, random keys for encryption.
- Regularly audit and update security configurations.

## Troubleshooting
- **Problem**: Failure to load certificates.
  **Solution**: Verify the certificate paths and file permissions.

- **Problem**: Decryption errors.
  **Solution**: Ensure the correct keys and associated data are used for decryption.

- **Problem**: SSL handshake failures.
  **Solution**: Check SSL/TLS versions and cipher configurations for compatibility.

!!! note
    For further assistance, refer to the official documentation or contact support.

"
}

docs.title: Storage
docs.text:
{
  "overview": "
# Overview

The **Vivified Storage Service** is a core component of the Vivified platform, providing robust, HIPAA-compliant storage capabilities for sensitive data, including PHI (Protected Health Information) and PII (Personally Identifiable Information). This service ensures data security through encryption, comprehensive audit logging, and strict retention policies.

## Key Features
- **Automatic Encryption**: All sensitive data is encrypted using advanced cryptographic techniques.
- **Data Classification**: Supports classification levels such as PUBLIC, INTERNAL, CONFIDENTIAL, PHI, and PII.
- **Audit Logging**: Detailed logging of all access and modifications to data.
- **HIPAA-compliant Retention Policies**: Supports standard retention periods to meet HIPAA requirements.
- **Multiple Storage Providers**: Integrates with Filesystem, S3, and potentially Azure.

!!! note
    This service is designed to be fully compliant with HIPAA regulations, ensuring secure handling of sensitive healthcare data.

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Client Application] -->|API Request| B[Storage Service];
    B -->|Encrypts Data| C[Storage Provider];
    C --> D{Filesystem};
    C --> E{S3};
    C --> F{Azure};
    B -->|Audit Log| G[Audit Service];
    B -->|Policy Check| H[Policy Engine];
```

!!! tip
    Use the appropriate StorageProvider for your infrastructure needs, such as S3 for cloud storage or Filesystem for on-premise solutions.
",
  "api": "
# API Reference

## StorageService Class

### Methods

#### `store_object(storage_object: StorageObject) -> StorageMetadata`
Stores an object and returns the updated metadata.

#### `retrieve_object(object_key: str) -> Optional[StorageObject]`
Retrieves an object by its key.

#### `delete_object(object_key: str) -> bool`
Deletes an object by its key.

#### `list_objects(query: StorageQuery) -> List[StorageMetadata]`
Lists objects matching the query.

!!! warning
    Ensure that all API requests are authenticated and authorized to maintain data integrity and security.
",
  "config": "
# Configuration Guide

## Storage Configuration Options

| Option              | Description                                                   | Default       |
|---------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------|---------------|
| `storage_provider`  | The storage backend to use (e.g., Filesystem, S3, Azure).    | `filesystem`  |
| `encryption_key`    | Master key for encryption of sensitive data.                  |               |
| `retention_policy`  | Data retention policy (e.g., SHORT_TERM, HIPAA_STANDARD).     | `HIPAA_STANDARD` |

!!! note
    Ensure that the encryption key is kept secure and not exposed in code or logs.
",
  "examples": "
# Usage Examples

## Store an Object

=== "Python"
    ```python
    from vivified.storage import StorageService, StorageObject

    storage_service = StorageService()
    obj = StorageObject(data="Sensitive Data", classification="PHI")
    metadata = await storage_service.store_object(obj)
    print(metadata)
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    curl -X POST \
      -H "Authorization: Bearer <token>" \
      -d '{"data": "Sensitive Data", "classification": "PHI"}' \
      https://api.vivified.com/storage/store
    ```

## Retrieve an Object

=== "Python"
    ```python
    metadata = await storage_service.retrieve_object("object_key")
    print(metadata)
    ```

=== "curl"
    ```bash
    curl -X GET \
      -H "Authorization: Bearer <token>" \
      https://api.vivified.com/storage/retrieve?object_key=object_key
    ```
",
  "security": "
# Security Considerations

- **Encryption**: All PHI/PII data is encrypted using AES 128 with HMAC for integrity.
- **Audit Logging**: Every action is logged with details including user, timestamp, and action type.
- **Access Control**: Ensure that the Policy Engine is configured to enforce trait-based access control.
- **Data Integrity**: Use consistent hashing to verify data integrity during storage and retrieval.

!!! warning
    Never share your encryption keys or tokens. Regularly rotate keys and tokens to enhance security.
",
  "troubleshooting": "
# Troubleshooting

## Common Issues

### Encryption Errors
- **Symptom**: "Encryption key not found."
- **Solution**: Ensure the `encryption_key` is configured correctly in the service settings.

### Access Denied
- **Symptom**: "403 Forbidden"
- **Solution**: Verify that the API token is valid and has the necessary permissions.

### Data Retrieval Issues
- **Symptom**: "Object not found"
- **Solution**: Check if the object key is correct and the object exists in the storage.

!!! tip
    Enable debug logging to get more detailed error messages that can assist in troubleshooting.
"
}

docs.title: Admin console
docs.text:
• :material-dashboard:{ .lg .middle } Admin Console

  • :material-settings:{ .lg .middle } Settings & Configuration

  • :material-dashboard_customize:{ .lg .middle } Plugin Management

Accessibility

All features must be accessible via the Admin Console per the Accessibility/Dyslexia Mandate.

No CLI-only Features

Operator actions, including plugin enablement and storage management, must be available via the UI.

Admin Privileges

Admin accounts grant wide access. Use MFA and role separation for production.

docs.title: Adding a plugin
docs.text:
PythonNode.jscurl 
# (1) Example: create plugin registration payload
payload = {"id":"com.example.plugin","name":"Example"}
requests.post('https://localhost:8443/api/v1/plugins/register', json=payload)

  • :material-key:{ .lg .middle } Authentication & RBAC

  • :material-history-edu:{ .lg .middle } Audit & Logs

API Usage

Use the Admin API for all management operations. Service-to-service interactions should use scoped service tokens.

Rate Limits

Admin API enforces rate limits for management endpoints. Monitor via /metrics.

Credentials

Use short-lived tokens and rotate them regularly.

• :material-settings:{ .lg .middle } Configuration Reference

  • :material-key:{ .lg .middle } Secrets & Keys

  • :material-tune:{ .lg .middle } Tuning & Retention

Centralized Config

Use the Admin Console to manage most runtime configuration. For infra-level config use environment variables and secrets management.

Defaults

Reasonable defaults are provided but must be reviewed for compliance before production use.

Critical

Never store production secrets in plaintext or checked-in files.

import os
ADMIN_API_PORT = int(os.getenv('ADMIN_API_PORT', '8443'))

Overriding defaults

Prefer Admin Console overrides for runtime tuning; reserve env vars for infra-level secrets.

docs.title: Configuration validation
docs.text:
• The platform validates configuration at startup and surfaces errors in logs and the Admin Console.
Validation Behavior Action Missing required key Startup fail Provide key or secret Invalid type Startup fail Correct type

Pro Tip

Use CI to run a config lint step that loads configs with test values to catch type errors early.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
• :material-rocket:{ .lg .middle } Quick Start

    Start the Vivified platform locally and access the Admin Console

  • :material-rocket-launch:{ .lg .middle } Local CI Parity

    Run exactly what CI runs before every push

  • :material-account-circle:{ .lg .middle } User Setup

    Create admin users and initial configuration

Quick Tip

Create a Python 3.11 virtual environment and pin versions to match CI for deterministic behavior.

Implementation Note

The local CI parity steps mirror CI and must be run before pushing. This prevents the "THIS MANY ERRORS" flood.

Security Warning

Do not expose sensitive credentials in examples. Use environment variables and a secrets manager.

docs.title: Table of contents
docs.text:
• Prerequisites
  • Local Preflight (recommended)
  • Start Services (dev)
  • Admin Console Access
  • Next steps

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.11
  • Node 20.x (optional for Admin UIs)
  • Docker (for local containerized runs)

Environment Note

Use Ctrl+C / Ctrl+V to copy commands into terminals. Use a dedicated developer machine or container for sensitive PHI/PII testing.

Why Python 3.11?

Python 3.11 matches CI. Using different Python versions causes subtle mypy/flake8 mismatches.

docs.title: Local Preflight (recommended)
docs.text:
Follow these steps exactly as CI runs them. This ensures parity and keeps branch protection green.

Step Command Purpose Status Create venv python3.11 -m venv .venv Isolate dependencies Required Install deps pip install -r core/requirements.txt black==25.9.0 ... Match CI pinned tools Required Lint black --check core/; flake8 core/ Code style & quality Required Typecheck mypy --config-file mypy.ini core/ Static typing Required Tests PYTHONPATH=$PWD pytest -q Unit/integration tests Required

Success

If all checks pass locally you have strong confidence CI will pass. Use pre-commit to automate this.

PythonNode.jscurl 
# (1) Create and activate venv
python3.11 -m venv .venv  # (2)
. .venv/bin/activate
# (3) Install dependencies
pip install -r core/requirements.txt \
  black==25.9.0 flake8==7.3.0 mypy==1.18.2 sqlalchemy==2.0.23 \
  pytest pytest-cov pytest-asyncio

// (1) Optional: ensure Node 20.x or lts/* is used
// (2) In core/ui and core/admin_ui
// npm ci && npm run build

# (1) Example healthcheck against Admin API
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer $ADMIN_TOKEN" https://localhost:8443/admin/health
  1. Use Python 3.11 for parity
  2. Pinned tool versions mirror CI
  3. Tests must pass locally before pushing

docs.title: Start Services (development)
docs.text:
Follow this checklist to start services locally (non-production).

  • Create venv and install deps
  • Run database migrations (if using local DB)
  • Start core services via docker-compose or make targets
PythonNode.jscurl 
# (1) Run a lightweight dev server (example)
export FLASK_ENV=development
PYTHONPATH=$PWD python -m core.app

// (1) Start Admin UI in dev mode
cd core/admin_ui
npm ci
npm run dev

# (1) Smoke test API
curl -k https://localhost:8443/api/v1/health
  1. Lightweight dev server for API
  2. Admin UI dev server
  3. Quick smoke test endpoint

mermaid graph LR Dev[Developer Machine] -->|Run preflight| LocalCI[Local CI Parity] LocalCI -->|Start| API[Admin API] LocalCI --> UI[Admin UI] API --> DB[(Database)] API --> Storage[Encrypted Storage]

Local CI Parity Details

Running the make ci-local target (if provided) bundles lint/type/test steps and mirrors CI.

docs.title: Admin Console Access

• Default URL: https://localhost:8443/admin/ui
  • Recommended: use a browser profile that isolates cookies and sessions.
Item Default Notes HIPAA Admin Console URL /admin/ui SPA served by Admin API Compliant Login OAuth2 / SSO RBAC enforced Compliant

Critical

Never use production credentials in local environments. Use test accounts or ephemeral tokens.

  • Read plugin development guide in /docs/plugins/

  • Explore API Reference /docs/api-reference.md
